metadata.title: Functional Capacity EvaluationIncluded tasks vary and are usually based on job analysis. Standardized procedures for assessing each task vary from FCE to FCE •Items in the WorkWell FCE –Floor to waist lift –Waist to overhead lift –Horizontal lift –Front carry –Right carry –Left carry –Elevated work –Crawl –5-min.  kneel –1-min.  kneel –1-min.  crouch –Squatting –Static push –Static pull –5-min.  trunk flex in sit –5-min.  trunk flex in stand –Rotation in sitting –Rotation in standing –Stair climbing –Stepladder climbing –Balance –Bending in standing –30-min.  standing –Walking –Handgrip strength –Hand coordination •Aerobic fitness is often included in pre-employment testing(4) in order to determine whether a person has sufficient aerobic capacity to perform required tasks and as a predictor of injury(4) –Researchers of a study conducted in Canada found the results of the 6-minute  walk test (6MWT) to be strongly associated with physical functional capacity on the Short Form-36 Health Survey in both obese and non-obese  individuals (N = 351) and suggested that the 6MWT reflects physical limitations in ADLs(26)
description: Functional capacity evaluation (FCE) is an umbrella term that refers to a set of tests and observations that evaluate a person’s physical ability to perform work activities related to his or her participation in employment(1)

The International Classification ofFunctioning, Disability, and Health (ICF) provides standard language that can be universally applied to what classifies health and disability. Tools such as FCEs draw upon its classifications to assist in assessing varying aspects of health such as work functioning(32)
FCEs are commonly used internationally to determine a person’s physical capacity to work, identify modifications needed, and/or recommend the need for vocational rehabilitation(12)
Many versions of FCEs are currently available and used clinically, with wide variation in the items tested(2)
FCEs are typically used after a workers’ compensation claim to determine if an injury will inhibit a worker’s ability to return to work(2,3)

Some employers may be required by law to administer an FCE before an employee can return to work, and some insurers may require an FCE before insurance payments can be made. FCEs are also used to determine eligibility for disability insurance payments or pension eligibility when an employee is permanently unable to return to work(3)
A job-specific  FCE focuses on returning a worker to specific job tasks, whereas a generic FCE may be used for case closure(3)
indications: To determine readiness for work after injury or illness (including full duty, modified/ transitional duty)
To assess treatment progress as part of goal setting
To determine need for vocational rehabilitation or remedial programs (e.g., work hardening)
To assess ability to meet job demands (pre-employment/post-job  offer screening)as part of the hiring process
To determine potential for litigation and possible damage awards

CPT codes.97750: Physical performance test or measurement with written report, each 15 minutes

reimbursement: Reimbursement may vary depending on who requests the FCE. The FCE may be paid for by workers’ compensation insurance plans, self-insured  plans, individual insurance plans, state and/or local agencies, managed care plans, or private pay. Rates may vary based on geography. Precertification of the service and verification of the state fee schedule are advised
contraindications precautions to test: Prevention of further injury during the testing process is the primary safety focus of FCEs. Clinicians should intervene if task performance begins to appear unsafe

Standardized criteria for stopping a test must be established in advance. These should include the following: –Onset of pain or increased pain –Nausea –Dizziness –Fatigue/shortness of breath –Blurred vision –Radicular symptoms –Continued use of unsafe body mechanics

Cardiovascular monitoring is required during the evaluation –The FCE should be modified if there are any excessive increases or decreases in heart rate, blood pressure, or respiratory rate  –Note if the patient has any cardiac restrictions or parameters for vitals
Obtain any other restrictions/precautions from the physician (e.g., weight-bearing  precautions, ROM, or lifting restrictions after surgery)
Only the required testing should be performed (i.e., testing should focus on critical job demands)

Psychophysical testing, in which the participant is allowed to determine when his or her safe maximal lift is reached, is potentially unsafe, particularly for pre-employment testing(4) –A participant may be motivated to attempt to exceed his or her safe ability to secure employment or may be unfamiliar with the work-related  equipment –Kinesiophysical testing, which relies on the ability of the test administrator to observe signs that indicate that the participant has reached his or her maximum ability, appears to be safer.(4) Signs include increases in heart rate and deterioration of movement patterns and body mechanics, as well as changes in joint kinematics(28)
psychometric properties: Reliability –Reliability of physical effort determination has been reported to vary substantially between tests within an FCE, ranging from unacceptable to good(5) -Regular education and training are recommended to improve the reliability of observational criteria for effort determination –Reliability has been tested for various components of specific FCEs in specific populations, including: -Good to excellent interrater and intra-rater reliability with injured workers in the manual handling components of the WorkHab FCE(6) -Substantial levels of test-retest  reliability in the manual handling components of the WorkHab FCE in healthy adults(7) -Moderate to excellent test-retest  reliability in the 12 tests of the whiplash-associated  disorders (WADs) FCE in patients with grade I or II WADs(8) -Researchers found that the reproducibility (i.e., agreement and inter-rater  reliability) of two task-specific  FCE protocols (using either two-wheeled  containers or bags) for waste collection workers was the following:(24) -Excellent agreement but poor interrater reliability for two-wheeled  container protocol -Acceptable agreement and good interrater reliability for the bag protocol -In a systematic review that included 11 studies, weight handling and strength test components of the WorkWell Systems FCE were found to have acceptable reliability.(15) Further research is needed to determine the reliability of the other components(15) -Patients had musculoskeletal disorders in 5 studies, chronic musculoskeletal pain in 1 study, and WADs in 1 study. Three studies evaluated healthy subjects, and the health status of subjects in 1 study was unclear -The Valpar Joule FCE has high interrater reliability, with an intraclass correlation (ICC) of > 0.90when tested on healthy adults(28) –A short-form  hand FCE protocol has been found reliable compared to the full-length  protocol in healthy subjects(16)

Validity –A review of several types of FCEs found variable results, but most showed moderate to good validity(33) -The WorkWell FCE has been shown to have modest predictive validity for return to work (RTW) in claimants with back and upper extremity (UE) injuries, but does not predict future injury occurrence(2) -Criterion-related  validity of the Ergo-Kit  FCE was found to be moderate to poor in a study of the concurrent and predictive validity (the 2 components of criterion-related  validity) in construction workers(9) -Concurrent validity was tested against the Instrument for Disability Risk, a tool for identifying construction workers at risk for disability, since no gold standard exists to which the FCE can be compared -Concurrent validity with future disability risk was poor for 2 of 5 specific lifting tasks and moderate for the other 3 -Predictive validity on durable RTW was poor -The authors concluded that the expectation that FCEs measuring current physical work ability have prognostic value for future work-related  concepts may be unrealistic –Predictive value of FCE tests improves as the occupational or physical demands approach or exceed the worker’s capability(4)  –Construct validity was also confirmed for a majority of FCE tests (handgrip strength, lifting waist to overhead, overhead working, and repetitive reaching) in patients with WADs with cultural differences in a workers’ compensation setting(25) –Authors of a 2013 study of the construct validity of FCE tests examined relationships between FCE tests and ICF factors(10) -In a sample of 403 healthy workers, material-handling FCE tests were related to physical factors but not to psychosocial factors tested -Only 5–15%  of static (postural) FCE test results were explained by physical or psychosocial factors -The construct of static work FCE tests remains largely unexplained –In a study conducted in Israel, there was higher agreement between the determined degree of disability based on medical examination alone and a combined medical examination and FCE in a population of patients with hip injury following traffic accident than in a group with WADs(17) –More validity research is needed, but evidence for the predictive ability of short-form  FCEs for RTW of injured workers is promising(4) –Job-specific  FCEs show better predictive validity in relation to the RTW of patients with a specific injury, such as a distal radius fracture, than in relation to the RTW of patients with a nonspecific injury(11)

Internal consistency –The examination typically uses repeated measures to account for effort and behavioral discrepancies(3) –Intra-test  inconsistency that exceeds normal error values is assumed to be an indicator of less than full effort if the test has been administered properly -Identification of measures of related attributes has allowed standards for inter-test  comparisons to be developed as indicators of effort. Absence of expected relationships among related measures suggests less than full effort –Some FCEs, such as the WorkWell, require testing on 2 consecutive days. Some items are tested twice. The need for repeated testing was investigated in a study conducted in the Netherlands involving subjects with early osteoarthritis(12) -Acceptable 2-day  consistency was found on 3 repeated test items: lifting low, lifting overhead, and carrying -The need for repeated testing on 2 consecutive days could not be confirmed

Psychometric properties are important and help to determine FCE choice, but often there are other factors that should also be considered, including cost, time spent on the assessment, user-friendliness,  and acceptability(33)
potential complications adverse effects: Pain exacerbation and muscle soreness are common after lengthy protocols(2)

In a study involving 197 healthy, working subjects, 82% reported a pain response following an FCE(13) –Descriptive statistics were used to compare the pain response to the pain response of patients with chronic low back pain from a previous study –The intensity of the pain response 24 hours post FCE was a median of 3.0 on a numeric 0–10  pain scale. Most of the pain was muscle soreness, with upper legs, lower back, shoulders, and upper arms being the most common locations –Symptoms decreased to pre-FCE  levels in a mean of 3 days –The pain response of healthy subjects, measured by its intensity and duration, was not significantly different from the response of patients with chronic low back pain –It was concluded that a pain response following an FCE can be expected and is a normal musculoskeletal reaction

Test interpretation is subject to the evaluator’s qualifications and experience(3) and the quality of the test –If an evaluator or a test unfairly identifies a patient who is not performing at maximum as a malingerer, this opinion or label could have a significant negative consequence for a person with a disability, including loss of access to necessary medical services and loss of financial support

Significant changes in kinematics can occur between lifts at minimum and safe maximum loads that are recognizable by trained therapists –Researchers of a study conducted in Australia identified these kinematic differences in 28 healthy participants during floor-to-bench  lifts, supporting the assessment of the therapist as to what is a safe maximal lift(23)
test preparation materials required: FCEs are normally conducted by allied health professionals, including PTs with special training and certification
Equipment requirements vary, from minimal equipment or workplace-based  tools to electronic computerized equipment and models(4)
test procedure: Included tasks vary and are usually based on job analysis. Standardized procedures for assessing each task vary from FCE to FCE

Items in the WorkWell FCE –Floor to waist lift –Waist to overhead lift –Horizontal lift –Front carry –Right carry –Left carry –Elevated work –Crawl –5-min.  kneel –1-min.  kneel –1-min.  crouch –Squatting –Static push –Static pull –5-min.  trunk flex in sit –5-min.  trunk flex in stand –Rotation in sitting –Rotation in standing –Stair climbing –Stepladder climbing –Balance –Bending in standing –30-min.  standing –Walking –Handgrip strength –Hand coordination

Aerobic fitness is often included in pre-employment testing(4) in order to determine whether a person has sufficient aerobic capacity to perform required tasks and as a predictor of injury(4) –Researchers of a study conducted in Canada found the results of the 6-minute  walk test (6MWT) to be strongly associated with physical functional capacity on the Short Form-36 Health Survey in both obese and non-obese  individuals (N = 351) and suggested that the 6MWT reflects physical limitations in ADLs(26)
test scoring interpretation: One limitation of FCEs is the problem of differentiating capacity from effort.(4) It is difficult to determine what a worker can do versus what he or she will do
Scoring procedures do not determine a person’s physical abilities independent of clinical judgment

Normative values for typical tests in an FCE have been established for healthy working subjects between 20 and 60 years of age(1) –Seven hundred one healthy volunteers in the Netherlands were recruited to perform the following work-related  tests in an FCE based on the WorkWell FCE:(1) -Material handling – in kg (lifting low, lifting high, carrying) -Postural work – time position held in seconds (overhead working, forward bend stand) -Coordination and repetitive tasks – time needed to complete task in seconds (dynamic bending, repetitive side reaching, hand and forearm dexterity); average number of pins placed in 30 seconds (fingertip dexterity) -Hand and finger strength – dynamometer readings  -Energetic capacity – prediction of maximum oxygen consumption in metabolic equivalents (METs) using Bruce treadmill test

Use of normative data for FCE is controversial for the assessment of patients for work ability(18) –Results of a study in the Netherlands indicate that use of normative values may lead to over-interpretation  of results and can lead to statements that have potential harmful consequences for work ability of patients –Forty-three  FCE experts working in insurance or occupational or rehabilitation medicine attending a focus group meeting participated in the study

Authors of a 2018 systematic review of the literature concluded that social factors affect performance during FCEs(30) –Thirteen studies were included, with 11 social factors considered –The social factors influencing FCEs were the following: -Healthcare provider -Examiner’s fear -Type of instruction -Personal and cultural systems -Country of FCE -Primary mother language -Ethnicity -Workplace system -Previous job salary -Time of workday -Legislative and insurance system -Compensation -Litigation status

Multiple social factors were found to affect FCE results in the assessment of musculoskeletal disorders in a multi-country study(31) –The study included 372 patients, 54 clinicians, 18 facilities, and 8 countries –All FCE measures (floor-to-waist  lift, 6-minute  walk, and handgrip strength) were affected by biopsychosocial factors –The patients’ height, reported pain intensity, clinician, and country in which the evaluation took place had the most effect on FCE measures

In a study conducted in the United States, significant differences in sincerity of effort determinations were found between White and non-White  (majority Latino/Latina) groups and between English-  and Spanish-speaking  workers(19) –No significant differences in sincerity of effort were noted between sex and age groups –These results suggest that a worker’s ethnicity and primary language spoken should be considered when “unreliable” outcomes are obtained in an FCE

Results of a study conducted in Switzerland suggest that interpretation of FCE results in patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain should include assessment of Waddell signs(20) –Waddell signs are a group of signs that indicate a nonorganic or psychological component to chronic low back pain(21) -Considered indicative of symptom magnification or pain behavior -Tests include distraction tests (positive tests are rechecked when patient is distracted), tenderness tests (e.g., for nonanatomic tenderness), simulation tests (tests based on movements that can produce pain without including the actual movement), and tests for overreaction –One hundred ninety-eight  patients referred for fitness-for-work  evaluation participated –Outcome measures were Waddell signs and performance during -manual handling, assessed with lifting from floor to waist, waist to crown, horizontal and one-handed carry -grip strength, assessed with dynamometer -ambulation, assessed with stair climbing and 6MWT -work postures with elevated work, forward bend stand, kneeling, and sitting –Thirty-three  percent of patients presented with positive Waddell signs –FCE performance in patients with positive Waddell signs differed significantly from that of patients with negative Waddell signs in all comparisons except grip strength of the dominant hand and sitting in females –Patients with chronic, nonspecific low back pain without Waddell signs demonstrated a capacity for substantial physical work demands

Researchers of a cluster RCT conducted in Canada compared results from FCEs with functional interviews in 225 workers’ compensation claimants. The results from the FCEs indicated higher baseline functional work levels but not improved return to work rates or functional work levels at follow-up  when compared to the functional interview group results(27) –The authors also suggested that the functional interviews have the potential for revealing a higher likelihood of clinically important improvement, as they were able to distinguish improvement in pain intensity, self-reported disability, and functional work level after rehabilitation but FCEs did not –The interviews questioned the ability of the claimants to perform the various activities on the WorkWell FCE protocol by asking them what level they would be able to maximally perform. The FCE group completed the 1-day  WorkWell FCE

Toaddress many of the limitationsidentified in studies, research is ongoing in rehabilitation robotics. Using robotics to both improve assessment and simulate workplace tasks has great potential for improving the FCE process(34)
